unnormalised: **Environmental News: Wildlife Conservation Efforts in India Gain Momentum**
normalised: **Environmental News: Wildlife Conservation Efforts in India Gain Momentum**

unnormalised: New Delhi – India’s commitment to wildlife conservation continues to strengthen, with notable progress reported across several key initiatives. The Project Tiger, launched decades ago, has seen a significant increase in tiger populations, particularly in reserves like Bandipur National Park in Karnataka.
normalised: New Delhi – India’s commitment to wildlife conservation continues to strengthen, with notable progress reported across several key initiatives. The Project Tiger, launched decades ago, has seen a significant increase in tiger populations, particularly in reserves like Bandipur National Park in Karnataka.

unnormalised: A recent survey, concluded on 26/01/2024, indicates a healthy growth rate, attributed to improved habitat management and anti-poaching measures. The Wildlife Institute of India (WII) in Dehradun is playing a crucial role, training forest officials and conducting crucial research. Their recent report, released at 09:00 hrs yesterday, emphasizes the importance of community participation in conservation efforts.
normalised: A recent survey, concluded on twenty sixth January two thousand and twenty four, indicates a healthy growth rate, attributed to improved habitat management and anti-poaching measures. The W I I in Dehradun is playing a crucial role, training forest officials and conducting crucial research. Their recent report, released at nine A M yesterday, emphasizes the importance of community participation in conservation efforts.

unnormalised: Furthermore, initiatives like the ‘Save the Elephant’ campaign, crucial in states like Kerala and Assam, are raising awareness about human-elephant conflict mitigation. Experts believe sustainable ecotourism models can provide economic benefits to local communities, further incentivizing wildlife protection. The government plans to allocate Rs. 50 crore towards habitat restoration projects in the next fiscal year. A national workshop on biodiversity will be held on 15/08/2024, focusing on the conservation of endemic species found within a 200 km radius of the Western Ghats. The legacy of conservation efforts, building on the principles enshrined in the Constitution since 15/08/1947, continues to inspire.
normalised: Furthermore, initiatives like the ‘Save the Elephant’ campaign, crucial in states like Kerala and Assam, are raising awareness about human-elephant conflict mitigation. Experts believe sustainable ecotourism models can provide economic benefits to local communities, further incentivizing wildlife protection. The government plans to allocate rupees fifty crore towards habitat restoration projects in the next fiscal year. A national workshop on biodiversity will be held on fifteenth August two thousand and twenty four, focusing on the conservation of endemic species found within a two hundred kilometer radius of the Western Ghats. The legacy of conservation efforts, building on the principles enshrined in the Constitution since fifteenth August nineteen forty seven, continues to inspire.
